hawaiian_text: He keiki ‘u‘uku loa ‘o **a)** Nāmakaokapāo‘o, a he  keiki ikaika loa i kona wā ‘ōpiopio, ‘a‘ohe ona lua  ma kēia mau mokupuni mai Hawai‘i ā Ni‘ihau, i ka  ‘u‘uku a me ke koa loa. **b1)** ‘O Kauluakaha‘i, kona   makua kāne, **c)** no Kahikipapaialewa, he ‘āina i  Kahikinu‘u. **b2)** ‘O Pōka‘ī ka makuahine. **c)** He ali‘i  nui kona makua kāne no Kahikipapaialewa, a **b1)** he ‘ao‘ao akua kekahi ona.
kimi-k2-fireworks_translation: Nāmakaokapāo'o was a very small child, and an extremely strong one in his youth, without equal throughout these islands from Hawai'i to Ni'ihau, in his small size and great bravery. Kauluakaha'i was his father, from Kahikipapaialewa, a land in Kahiki-nu'u. Pōka'ī was the mother. His father was a high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, and was also partly divine.
kimi-k2-fireworks_commentary:
**Paragraph 1:** • This opening paragraph follows classic Hawaiian narrative conventions that date back to the earliest oral traditions and remain consistent throughout all major Hawaiian mo'olelo: **a)** the protagonist and their exceptional physical/spiritual attributes are introduced first; **b)** the genealogy and location of both parents are established; **c)** the specific geographical and political context is situated.

• **a)** Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo'o (the eyes of the pāo'o fish) - this name carries profound symbolic weight. The pāo'o (common name: manini) is renowned for its exceptional eyesight and its ability to see clearly in turbulent waters. The name functions as an archetype of prophetic vision and future sight, suggesting that this child will "see" what others cannot. The repetition of "loa" (very) in 'u'uku loa (very small) and ikaika loa (very strong) creates a natural tension that establishes the protagonist's unique nature - small in physical form but enormous in spiritual power. The phrase "He keiki ikaika loa... 'a'ohe ona lua" establishes that his strength is not merely physical but encompasses mana (spiritual power) - a child who has "no second" or equal across the entire archipelago. This hyperbolic claim serves a dual function: establishing the child's supernatural birthright while setting up the reader/listener for stories that will demonstrate such prowess.

• **b1)** Ka-ulu-a-kaha'i (the inspiration/trace of Kaha'i) - this genealogical name places the child in direct descent from Kaha'i, a major Hawaiian demigod-hero who traveled to Kahiki and brought back both breadfruit (according to some traditions) and the knowledge/skills needed for navigation and agriculture. The name "Kaha'i" itself means "to cause to grow" or "to mark out," suggesting both agricultural and navigational expertise. Linking this child to Kaha'i through the father's name establishes an aristocratic lineage that transcends mere mortals.

• **c)** Kahiki-papa-ia-lewa (the Kahiki stratum that floats suspended) - this is a mythical realm that appears consistently in Hawaiian cosmology as "Kahiki-nu'u" (the elevated Kahiki). Rather than a simple foreign land, it represents a liminal space between the mortal realm and the realm of the gods. The phrase "he 'āina i Kahiki-nu'u" indicates that the father's origins are not merely from outside Hawai'i but from a place that exists conceptually between earth and heaven. This serves multiple cultural functions: it maintains the separation between the divine and mortal while establishing the child's mixed nature; it preserves the hierarchical nature of Hawaiian society by associating aristocratic status with foreign divine origins; and it creates narrative possibilities for actions that transcend normal human limitations.

**b2)** Pō-ka-'ī (night falls upon the supreme one) - the mother's name follows typical Hawaiian patterns where the mother's name is simply stated without elaborate description, reflecting 'Ai Kapu era social structures where maternal lineage was subordinate to paternal. The name carries undertones of darkness and concealment, perhaps suggesting that the mother herself possesses hidden powers or secrets.

• **b1)** The phrase "he 'ao'ao akua kekahi ona" (some portion of deity he possesses) continues an ancient genealogical convention where aristocratic/historical figures demonstrate their right to power through divine ancestry. This is not merely a claim of personal divinity but a statement of socio-political legitimacy. In Hawaiian thought, this divine portion (mana) is inherited but must be continually demonstrated/proven through action - a child can lose or gain mana through their own deeds. This sets up the narrative tension that will drive subsequent stories: how will Nāmakaokapāo'o manifest the divine portion he has inherited?

• The geographic sweep "mai Hawai'i ā Ni'ihau" represents the fullest possible expression of the Hawaiian universe in traditional cartography - the southeastern corner (Hawai'i Island, the first-born island) to the northwestern boundary (Ni'ihau). This serves as shorthand for "throughout the entire known world" and places the child's uniqueness in universal rather than local terms.

reference_translation: Nāmakaokapāo‘o was a little boy and incredibly  strong when he was very young. There was no one  like him from Hawai‘i all the way to Ni‘ihau in his  small stature and bravery. Kauluakaha‘i was his  father from Kahikipapaialewa, a place in  Kahikinu‘u. Pōka‘ī was his mother. His father was a  high chief of Kahikipapaialewa, who was also part  god.
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 1:**• It is very common in Hawaiian storytelling to open by  disclosing:  **a)** the name of the main protagonist/s, and   sometimes a description of their (aproximate) age  and/or physique/physical attributes;  **b)** the name of the parent/s, grandparent/s,  caregiver/s of the main protagonist/s, and sometimes  a description;  **c)** the name of the place the main protagonist/s grew  up or are living in at the time the story takes place;  • The main protagonists described in the first  paragraph are:  1\) Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o (m) (the eyes of the pāo‘o  fish): an incredibly strong, young boy, with no  comparison from Hawai‘i to Ni‘ihau for his small  stature and strength; 2\) Ka-ulu-a-kaha‘i (m) (the inspiration of Kaha‘i (Footnote: Pukui & Elbert (1977:385): Kaha‘i: “A hero who traveled to ‘Upolu, Samoa, and brought back breadfruit to Haki-pu‘u, Oahu (according to some versions) or to Pu‘u-loa, Kohala,  Hawaii (HM 97). He was born at ‘Ī-ao, Maui. He went to Kahiki to find his father, Hema, who had lost his eyes (HM 248). See Nā-maka-o-Kaha‘i.), Nā maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s father; a high chief of Kahiki-papa ia-lewa (Kahiki stratum in the sky, likely a foreign  country), a place in Kahiki-nu‘u (Kahiki at the summit,  a foreign country); he is a demigod;  3\) Pō-ka-‘ī (f) (perhaps ʻnight falls upon the high  chief’): Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o’s mother; no further  description;
